Observation/Comments: Underground fire service routing from street to building is labeled “FOR HYDRAULIC REFERENCE ONLY (UG BY OTHERS)” with no pipe sizes, materials, or valve configuration; coordination and responsibility for final design/installation unclear.
Fire department connection (FDC) piping arrangement and backflow location not clearly dimensioned from building or property lines; constructability and AHJ access need clarification.
Hydrant locations are shown but no dimensions to building, FDC, or fire lanes; ability to meet required hose distances and vehicle access during potential flood events is unclear.

Flow test data provided without explicit reference to test date validity window or safety factor to be applied in hydraulic calculations; need confirmation that data is current and design margin is defined.
Coordination between site fire water service and building fire riser entry not detailed (no elevation, thrust blocks, or tie-in detail); risk of field conflicts with other utilities.
No indication of valve pits, post indicator valves, or sectional valves on underground main; isolation strategy for building fire protection system unclear.
Penetration and sleeve details for fire service entry through foundation/walls not clearly tied to specific locations on plan; potential for uncoordinated fire-rated penetrations and waterproofing.
Sprinkler head layout is not shown on Level 1 plan (only piping/risers/standpipes indicated); compliance with NFPA sprinkler spacing and coverage cannot be verified.
Standpipe hose valve locations at stairs and exit passageways are not clearly dimensioned or labeled by floor level; confirmation of hose reach to remote areas is not possible.
Fire riser room layout, clearances, and separation from other uses are not detailed on this plan; need dedicated room configuration and door access information.
Coordination of sprinkler piping with structural beams and mechanical ductwork is not depicted; potential for field conflicts and hidden obstructions to sprinkler discharge.
No explicit indication of fire-rated wall penetrations or required firestopping details where FP mains cross rated assemblies; continuity of fire ratings cannot be confirmed.
No coordination shown between sprinkler piping and varying ceiling heights/soffits at lobby and amenity areas; risk of concealed or obstructed heads under soffits.
Plan appears to show mechanical and FP routing together but individual sprinkler head locations and spacing are not indicated; NFPA coverage and spacing compliance cannot be verified.
No clear indication of sprinkler head type (concealed, sidewall, etc.) or location relative to corridor and room soffits; potential for spacing/obstruction issues at door headers and bulkheads.
Coordination between FP standpipes and mechanical pressurization ducts in stair and shaft spaces is not detailed; risk of conflicts or inadequate clearances.
Exterior balcony/terrace areas adjacent to building envelope do not clearly show whether sprinklers are required or provided; potential unsprinklered special hazard areas.
Large open parking/amenity area shows grid but individual sprinkler heads and spacing not clearly indicated; ability to meet maximum coverage and spacing requirements is unclear.
Sprinkler protection at parking ramps and sloped decks is not detailed (head locations vs. slope/clearances not shown); need confirmation of coverage and obstruction-free discharge.
Standpipe riser and hose valve locations at Level 3 not clearly called out; verification of required hose reach and intermediate landing valves is not possible.
Seismic bracing for FP piping is not indicated on this level despite likely requirement for braced mains in a high-rise; need bracing layout or reference to separate seismic bracing plan.
No callouts showing where FP mains penetrate rated stair and elevator core walls, nor associated firestopping details; risk of uncoordinated penetrations compromising ratings.
Sprinkler head spacing is not dimensioned; compliance with NFPA coverage criteria, especially in irregular perimeter and balcony areas, is unclear.
Coordination with architectural reflected ceiling plans is not shown; potential conflicts between sprinklers and soffits/ceiling transitions cannot be verified.
Sloped ceiling/ramps indicated but no specific details on sprinkler elevation adjustments or additional heads at high/low points; risk of shadowed areas.
Large beams/soffits shown without explicit obstruction notes or head relocation details; potential noncompliance with NFPA obstruction rules.
Standpipe riser routing and hose valve locations are not clearly indicated on this level; verification of required hose valve at each stair landing is not possible.
Penetrations for sprinkler piping through fire-rated walls/shafts are not detailed; firestopping and sleeve requirements are not identified.

FP drawing does not clearly show revised head locations relative to new walls/terraces; potential unsprinklered pockets or heads in wrong compartment.
No clear indication whether these are considered ordinary hazard or light hazard; design density/area assumptions and hazard classification not documented on plan.
Continuity of sprinkler mains/risers between Levels 4–6 is not diagrammed; contractor cannot confirm pipe sizes and connection points from this sheet alone.
Head spacing not dimensioned; irregular room geometries and corridors make it difficult to verify maximum spacing and distance from walls.

No explicit coordination notes between stair pressurization ductwork and standpipe/sprinkler piping; potential conflicts in tight shaft spaces.
Similar layout to Level 6 but without explicit keynotes for each head type; ambiguity whether concealed/pendant/sidewall types match ceiling conditions.
Sprinkler branch lines follow structure but no detail on hanger/seismic bracing for sloped piping; constructability of support and bracing is unclear.

Hose valve symbols are not clearly visible at each intermediate floor landing; confirmation of NFPA 14 hose valve placement is not possible.
Perimeter pink-highlighted areas suggest architectural changes but sprinkler layout does not clearly reflect revised boundaries; possible need for additional heads along new exterior walls.

Some small rooms off corridors do not clearly show sprinkler heads; verify all enclosed spaces above threshold size are protected.

Sprinkler spacing within dwelling units is not dimensioned; compliance with residential spacing rules and proximity to walls/obstructions is unclear.
Several balconies/terraces appear without clearly indicated sprinklers under overhead construction; clarify requirements and provide heads where code-mandated.
Standpipe and hose valve symbols are not clearly shown on typical floor plan; need explicit confirmation of hose valve at each required landing on all levels 14–23.

Related documents reference “Vibration Controls For Fire Protection Systems (Non-Seismic)” but there is no mention of seismic bracing or hangers if required by code for this project location; confirm whether seismic restraint of FP piping is required and, if so, identify governing spec section and design criteria.

Section lists “basic fire protection materials and methods” but does not clearly enumerate which FP systems (sprinklers, standpipes, pumps, alarms, etc.) are covered; clarify scope so required testing is not omitted.

Independent testing agency requirements are mentioned but no criteria for agency qualification or responsibility for engagement/payment are defined; request clarification for constructability and bidding.

Only “Automatic Wet-Type, Class I Standpipe System” is described; no indication if other standpipe classes/types are required elsewhere in building (e.g., Class III, combined systems), creating ambiguity for design and sizing.

Section includes “control panels” and “manual control stations” but no coordination reference to Division 28/26 for power, monitoring, and locations; potential conflict with fire alarm and electrical layouts.

“Complete system shall include all fire department connections, roof manifolds, hose stations…” but standpipe and hose station responsibilities may overlap with Section 21 12 00; clarify division of scope to avoid gaps/duplication.
Areas exposed to freezing are to have dry pipe systems, but no criteria or list of such areas is provided; contractor cannot determine extent of dry vs. wet without further direction.

Spec requires hydraulic calculations and AHJ/insurer approvals before work, but does not define required design criteria (density/area, hazard classifications by space, water supply data) on this page; constructability and pricing are unclear.

Section lists numerous fire-pump-related components (controllers, transfer switches, alarm panels, flowmeter systems) but does not indicate which are by FP vs. Electrical/Controls trades; need responsibility matrix for coordination.
Fire pump motor horsepower is to match an unspecified “Schedule”; schedule location and required duty point (gpm/psi) are not defined on this page, creating ambiguity for pump selection and pricing.

Shop drawing requirements list equipment details but do not state minimum clearances around pump, controller, and accessories for maintenance and code compliance; need explicit clearance criteria to coordinate fire pump room layout.
